column1: chartier 160872897441 "2017-05-20 13:50:31 GMT" http://blog.chartier.land/post/160872897441/europes-view-of-trump "robertreich:  European governments
column2: preparing for a round of major summits with Donald Trump
column3: are wary.  I spent much of the past week speaking with officials and cabinet ministers in Europe. All they wanted to talk about was Trump.Â  Here
column5: are the most frequent remarks I heard from them
column6: and from others in my travels
column7: in rough order of frequency: 1. Trump is unstable
column8: and weâ€™re not going to count on anything he says or commits to.  2. Trump doesnâ€™t support NATO or European integration.  3. Trump is actively encouraging racist nationalists in our country.  4. Trump is allied with Putin to bring Europe down.  5. Thereâ€™s no doubt Trump worked with Putin to win the U.S. presidential election. 6. If Trumpâ€™s polls drop too low
column9: heâ€™ll start a war in order to get Americans to rally around him. (Opinions varied on whether Trumpâ€™s war would be with North Korea
column14: or Afghanistan.) 7. How did you Americans come to elect this ego-maniac? (Others called him an infant
column20: Hitler). 9. We remember fascism. We never thought it would happen in America.  10. The world depends on American leadership. Weâ€™re very worried. My overall impression: Anti-Trump sentiment is even stronger in Europe than it is in the U.S. If Trump expects his European trip to give him a reprieve from his troubles at home

column1: chartier 160093901946 "2017-04-28 20:05:35 GMT" http://blog.chartier.land/post/160093901946/im-pretty-sure-logan-is-my-favorite-super-hero "And I enjoy Marvel films
column2: but Iâ€™m not a mega fan of them or even Wolverine. But Iâ€™ve been thinking about this a bit again. Logan dealt with the realities of being a mutant
column3: a human being
column4: and aging in a uniquely difficult
column5: incredible way. But I also actually sympathized with the antagonistâ€™s argumentâ€”to an extentâ€”for probably the first time ever for these films. For better and for worse
column6: itâ€™s also violent in a way no other Marvel film can even think about touching (parents and folks with weak stomachs: there are many
column7: many good reasons that itâ€™s R). But at the end of the day
column8: I actually appreciate it. It is legit difficult to watch the violence unfold
column10: which I feel is a metaphor for the difficulty of being him and being forced into these situations. The film tackles the reality of these characters in an incredibly personal way
column11: and letâ€™s face itâ€”Wolverine has freaking metal claws; he isnâ€™t back scratching or tickling anyone to death. Anyway. Incredible film. The academy probably wonâ€™t give it the credit it deserves
column12: but whatever. If you havenâ€™t seen it yet
column13: and youâ€™re interested in a fantastic drama about people in extraordinary situations
column14: who also happen to be mutants and super (anti-)heroes facing incredibly difficult personal problems and relationships
column15: see Logan. Itâ€™s just amazing." True text

column1: chartier 160019394511 "2017-04-26 18:02:53 GMT" http://blog.chartier.land/post/160019394511/the-under-appreciated-skill-of-esports-match "I donâ€™t watch a lot of esports
column2: but I check in on Vainglory matches every now and then (theyâ€™re running a few right now
column3: if youâ€™re interested
column4: as they work on applying a pretty big update to the servers). One thing Iâ€™ve grown to appreciate about the Vainglory match announcers Iâ€™ve heard is how damn good they are. Really
column5: bear with me. Vainglory is a competitive MOBA (multiplayer online battle arena) for iOS and Android
column6: with three players on each team. There are around 20 heroes to pick in the game
column7: all with unique abilities that have their own names
column9: and weaknesses. Abilities can apply greater damage
column14: and on and on. Vainglory also has an in-match shop from which every player buys attack
column16: and support items throughout the match (not in-app purchases; you earn in-match gold as you achieve objectives or kill enemies). There are probably 40-50 items
column19: and interactions. The Vainglory match announcers Iâ€™ve heard juggle the depth and breadth of all this stuff amazingly well. Theyâ€™re familiar with which items are more advantageous for certain characters. When abilities and attacks are triggered
column21: including whether something affected an enemy
column23: or got enhanced by a teammate
column24: and they do it all in the middle of crazy split-nanosecond team fights. Even if you arenâ€™t into or familiar with one of these games
column25: it might be worth checking out one of these matches to witness this first hand. I have a thing for MOBAs right now
column26: so Vainglory and League of Legends are good places to start." True text

column1: chartier 158272709586 "2017-03-11 16:24:41 GMT" http://blog.chartier.land/post/158272709586/techstandswithpp-a-message-from-tumblrs-ceo-and "plannedparenthood:  When Planned Parenthood was founded a century ago
column2: it was illegal to even hand out information about birth control. Thanks to generations of brave women and men who formed secret societies
column3: challenged unjust laws
column4: and started Planned Parenthood health centers in their own towns
column5: weâ€™ve come a long way since. Millions of people
column6: regardless of income or insurance coverage
column7: now have access to birth control
column9: and STI testing and treatment. Each year
column10: Planned Parenthood proudly provides health information to nearly 70 million people online and 1 million people in classrooms and communities across the country. Today
column11: America is at a 30-year low in unintended pregnancy and a historic low in teen pregnancy. But all of that progress is a reminder of how much women and men in America now stand to lose. Extreme politicians at every level of government are doing everything they can to block millions of people from coming to Planned Parenthood
column12: deny access to affordable health care
column13: and roll back womenâ€™s rights over their own bodies. We are facing a national health disaster
column14: especially in our most vulnerable communities. Thatâ€™s why weâ€™re calling on the tech industry to join Tumblr in standing with Planned Parenthood and standing up for access to health care. A 100-year-old health care provider and the platform powering 335 million blogs may seem like an unlikely pair. But over the last few years
column15: Tumblr and Planned Parenthood have teamed up to provide information and organize communities in support of reproductive rights. Weâ€™re proud of all weâ€™ve accomplished together and with overwhelming support from the Tumblr community. Technology has become instrumental in the fight for fairness and equality across a range of issues. It has the power to influence public debate
column17: and â€” most importantly â€” offer creative solutions to help people receive better care
column18: no matter where they live or who they are. Finally
column19: the tech industry owes its success to the brilliant people it employs and the communities it serves â€” and we cannot take their health for granted. It wonâ€™t be easy
column20: but doing nothing isnâ€™t an option when lives are at stake. We need to work together to break down barriers to care and information for the millions of people desperate to take ownership of their sexual and reproductive health
column21: and tackle disparities in health care access and outcomes. Now is the time to be vocal
column23: and active in your support of Planned Parenthood â€” starting with the #TechStandsWithPP hashtag to share stories about how Planned Parenthood has touched your life
column24: or the life of anyone you know. Call on your co-workers and peers to do the same. In health care
column27: weâ€™re doing things that would have been unthinkable a century ago. Think of all we can achieve together in the decades to come if we combine the creativity
column29: and energy of the tech community with Planned Parenthoodâ€™s commitment to helping people everywhere â€” no matter what. â€” David Karp + Cecile Richards " False text

column1: chartier 157163582166 "2017-02-12 22:22:17 GMT" http://blog.chartier.land/post/157163582166/pandaflavouredcookies-i-am-sick-and-tired-of "pandaflavouredcookies: I am sick and tired of these stupid videos going viral on facebook about how technology has made us antisocial and that social media is evil. Let me tell you a story. Iâ€™m half English
column2: but live in Spain. I get to see my English family
column3: at best
column4: once a year. Sometimes not even that. I love my English grandparents
column5: but we donâ€™t have many things in common. We can get a nice 20 minute talk going about what weâ€™ve been doing lately
column6: and then I usually fall silent whilst my mum talks about cooking with my grandma and my dad goes on to talk about science with my granddad. Itâ€™s so disappointing
column8: and I can only rely on their interest in what Iâ€™m doing with my life to start a conversation. A few months ago we flew to England and stayed with them a few days. Whilst having supper
column9: naturally (as always) the conversation started with how I was doing
column10: and what I was planning to do with my future now that I had graduated. I told them I was thinking about moving back to Japan to start working there. Somehow
column12: we started talking about life in Japan
column13: and my parents chipped in by commenting on their experience in Tokyo as tourists. â€œThereâ€™s so many people!â€ And then someone asked
column14: â€œwhatâ€™s the population of Japan?â€ And I said
column15: Â â€œLet me google that.â€ So I pulled out my smartphone.Â 127.3 million.Â Can you believe it? Thatâ€™s a lot! Thatâ€™s twice as much as the UK
column16: isnâ€™t it? What is the population of the UK? Granddad says 60 million
column17: but grandma says 62. Google says 64.1 million. What about Spain? 50 million
column21: says google. We all guessed at the population of the US
column24: of Germany; we cheered when one of us had almost hit the mark
column25: and gasped at unexpected numbers. We looked up the dates of historical events
column27: we searched Stonehenge on google maps and read about the theories behind it
column28: we googled â€˜disc symbols ancientâ€™ to try and figure outÂ what this paperweight my granddad had in his office was supposed to be because he couldnâ€™t remember its name and immediately found out it was a replica of theÂ Phaistos Disc.Â â€œâ€˜Disc symbols ancientâ€™! How did google know what we were looking for just from that? Thatâ€™s amazing!â€ We went on for hours
column29: and it was so. much. fun. For three whole hours
column31: every topic we talked about was somehow linked to googling facts or images on my smartphone
column32: and do you know what my granddad said to me as we started cleaning everything up? He said this thing I had was amazing
column33: and he wanted one too. Technology is not a conversation stopper. Itâ€™s a conversation starter
column34: and if you donâ€™t know how to be responsible
column35: if you donâ€™t know how to make use of this amazing thing we have to keep a conversations going
column38: or twitter. Itâ€™s you.  That punctuating
column39: reverberating sound you hear is a mic hitting the floor." False text
